Topic.Title: if you r here with a leaning to sell inspiration, go away we don't want any. ROFLMFO.

Message.Msg: I suppose I'd be sheet outta luck, but I don't need the help of amateur criminal psychologists like Dietz or shutupstellas or viewer or you now that Steve Wynn is on the case. The Celebrated Mr. W was in Everett Massachusetts the other day touting his grand vision for the former Monsanto chemical site, and his praise for those 30 acres of contaminated marshland makes me think he can overcome my own flattery deficit too. Viewer, are you open to relocation? Here's my sales pitch for Massachusetts: "It's expensive, but the weather sucks." Oh, and I know a good sushi joint. If you're nervous about our first date, how about a double-date? ROTFLMAO I'll bring shutupstellas along to put you more at ease. How's the service sector been treating you? And what breed is Mr. Martinez's dog? There have been some interesting developments in the Staggerwing Saga that have kept me kinda busy lately. Remember the problem I ran into trying to find original longerons for the Beech's damaged fuselage? Well, it turns out that there was a design flaw in the early Staggerwings that made them 'sluggish' about the pitch axis. I thought the thing was supposed to have the delicate pitch response of a cement mixer and liked the way my forearms got all pumped up like Popeye's whenever I flared for landings, although I didn't much care for the tendon-popping I experienced during the Cuban Eight over the Utah Day Care Center. Beech corrected the problem in 1936 and later Staggerwings by lengthening the fuselage a couple of feet aft of the cabin to give the tail assembly control surfaces more leverage, and the FAA issued an airworthiness directive requiring the modification to be incorporated on the earlier models, but somehow the news never caught up with my bird. It's amazing how the threat of a few lawsuits improves one's standing in the community. Flo has started calling me 'Sir' again; the FAA has grudgingly returned my pilot's license (but with a crop-dusting prohibition - apparently they feel the added weight of the tanks and sprayers was a contributor to the accident), and even the boys at the hangar have stopped calling me 'duhmass'. I'm considering suing my wife and daughter for emotional abuse to see if they'll stop calling me bad names too. Gotta go now; Mr. Otis is here to inspect my library elevator. Besides the odor, I'm gonna ask him if he knows why it never went all the way to the top. ROTFLMAO Dr. Nick sez I'm fine now, and who am I to argue with a medical professional?

Topic.Title: Once again I wil ask about volume of trading..

Message.Msg: First, the market is mostly driven by people's perceptions and emotions, not volume. The reason you see so much volume in BAC and certain other stocks is largely due to HTF (high frequency trading). BAC quite often has a trading range of .40 or more. HTF is driven by computers trading in and out of stocks at speeds only computers can achieve. That means that in a stock like BAC, the shares are being bought and sold over and over again, thus creating high volume. One can mistake that high volume as being driven by supply/demand. Sometimes it is, for example when stocks announce news or earnings. Largely, it is not. It is driven by a day trading mentality. Now, if you look at the volume and trading in and out of stocks at millions of shares a day, the ten or more cents per share one might make adds up to millions of dollars of profit or loss per day.

Topic.Title: Once again I wil ask about volume of trading..

Message.Msg: Stetchlee, you obviously don't know what how the DOW. Mostly, when people talk about the DOW, the are referring to the DOW Industrials, which is composed of 30 stocks of which BAC is one. So, it does not follow the DOW. It is one of the DOW components that create the moving average. That's why it appears to follow it. It's not. It's leading it.

Topic.Title: Once again I wil ask about volume of trading..

Message.Msg: Most of the headlines about BAC this year have been negative, except for actual company news and Qtr reports. That might lead people to short the stock more than buy to hold for profit. It also "tints" peoples opinion about the company. Remember, speculators trade based on their perceptions (what they think is going to happen) and their emotions ("I got to get out of this now and take the loss before I lose everything!") And let's face it, BAC mgmt has not missed one opportunity to shoot itself in the foot with negative PR. All of that said, anyone shorting BAC at this time of year is playing with fire and their hands will get burned. Statistically, the time of year that most of the profit on stocks is made is between October and March. That is the period when stocks hit their upsides. In fact, the statics show that if one invests in that time period as opposed to the rest of the year, over a 25 year period one's returns would be something like 10 times greater. Yes, there are exceptions to every rule, but that is a long standing and accurate statistic for many reasons, which I won't go into here. Now, with the advent of the internet, everything changed for the stock market, and especially the small retail speculator. Now, excluding insider knowlege, the small retail speculator (I think the term investing where stocks are concerned is now an oxymoron), has access to the same info and reaction times as big institutional investors. If I were advising someone today who was already a shareholder of BAC, that advice would be to wait until the 1/17 Q4 earnings call.Baring horrific economic news (which I don't see happening) I believe that by the middle of January, we will see this stock much closer to 15. Remember, it has a book value of almost 20 per share and an intrinsic value somewhere around 13. BAC has announced that it will hold its earnings call prior to market open, which is usually an indication of good news. My advice to those not in it at this point would be to play the Feb call options. Any downside position taken at this point might yield a small profit but will pale in comparison to the upside that is coming this January. Just my opinion.
